Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Investigating Cultural and Instructor Influences on Student Argumentation and Conceptual Understanding in Chemistry Classrooms
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports aimed at understanding how cultural norms and instructor implementation of course materials influence student argumentation and conceptual understanding of chemistry. It is important to analyze the nature of the communication used by both the students and the instructor. The team will investigate student ability to generate scientific arguments and the conceptual level (macroscopic, sub-microscopic, and symbolic) at which they discuss chemical concepts. The role of the instructor in encouraging student conversations and helping students make connections between the different conceptual levels will also be explored. Further analysis of the arguments will be used to describe classrooms norms. Analysis of classroom interactions will provide insight regarding the nature of classroom conversations, the influence of cultural norms, the nature and quality of student generated arguments, and students? conceptual understanding of chemistry. This research will be conducted at National Taiwan Normal University in collaboration with Dr. Hsin-Kai Wu, an internationally recognized expert on analyzing interactions between teachers, students, and technology in the classroom.

Transcripts of student dialogue in the classroom will be analyzed using Toulmin's Model of Argumentation to examine students' ability to generate scientific arguments. The representational levels for the arguments will then be identified using Johnstone's triangle. In addition, the Inquiry Oriented Discursive Moves Framework will be used to investigate the role of the instructor in encouraging student discourse and translation between different representational levels. Analysis of the course materials will help to examine the relationships between the nature of the materials and student reasoning, particularly with respect to the use of representations. Together this will allow the determination of the intertextuality and the links among the different aspects of a classroom learning environment. This NSF EAPSI award supports the research of a U.S. graduate student and is funded in collaboration with the Ministry of Science and Technology of Taiwan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of this study was to identify different instructor facilitation strategies and features of course materials that encourage students to engage in scientific argumentation and make connections between different chemistry concepts in physical chemistry. Argumentation is an important skills we want students to develop because this is essentially what scientists do in the lab. They collected data, make a claim, then explain how the data led them to their claim. By studying classroom conversations we able to better understand how students interact with their peers, their instructor, and the course materials to construct an understanding of chemistry.

It was found that if the instructor models scientific argumentation when interacting with students, students are more likely to generate arguments when discussing concepts with their peers. In addition, to encourage students to engage in argumentation and have meaningful discussion about chemistry concepts the instructor can prompt student to explain the reasoning behind their conclusions. This not only helps encourage students to make complete arguments but also helps them connect concepts and think about chemistry from a macroscopic perspective vs microscopic perspective and how we represent this information using symbolic representations in chemistry. The instructor also has an important role in facilitation of encouraging students to work collaboratively in groups. Just because students are placed together in groups does not mean they know how to work as a team to solve problems and construct a shared understanding of the content. It is up to the instructor to show students the benefits of working collaboratively and by working together they can solve problems that would be more difficult if done independently. This teamwork also helps students develop a shared understanding of the concepts they are supposed to be learning and gives students the opportunity to teach their peers if they are struggling. This is good for students because it has often been said that the best way to learn is to teach.

While the instructor was one influence on student learning in the classroom another is the course materials students’ use. By analyzing the course materials to see what information was provided to the students, we were better able to determine where students were pulling information from to incorporate into their arguments. Additional analysis of the materials has also helped identify features of questions that encourage students to engage in meaningful discussion about the concepts. It was found that questions that required students to think conceptually about content or interpret a model or equation most often resulted in student generated arguments. It was also found the questions that required students to do mathematical derivations resulted in students only thinking about the symbolic representation that was being used and not what the mathematical equation actually represents in terms of chemistry at the macroscopic and microscopic levels. It was determined that if we want students to make these connections then the materials should prompt students to think about what the mathematical equations mean conceptually. Furthermore, this analysis of the material has prompted the author to redesign the materials to better encourage students to engage in discussions about chemistry concepts at the symbolic, macroscopic, and microscopic levels.
